text: At Maison Yaki, in Prospect Heights, a pop-up series has showcased pastries from @BrutusBakeshop and Maryland-style fried chicken from the chef Jared Howard; next up are Southern- and Caribbean-inspired comforts from @iv_good (through August 16th). https://t.co/zuhZVujz6A

text: Lyonnais rice pilaf is made in the oven, and it achieves a surprisingly delicate puffy texture, as if it has been gently but moistly roasted. https://t.co/eVwb6waWYT

text: "I couldn’t help overhearing what Q and his pretty companion were saying to each other. It was a fairly complicated matter. I gave up trying to read and listened to them." New flash fiction by Haruki Murakami. https://t.co/ipi1wY5wDY

text: In the U.S., we have been undergoing a kind of four-year experiment in what happens to a country when social trust and social capital are not merely badly maintained but actively corroded, @AdamGopnik writes. https://t.co/S3KAxSI7mc

text: Once a distant outpost of the British Empire, the Falkland Islands have become a global crossroads. As the coronavirus looms, the intimate communities may be remade again. https://t.co/5PqJsRO5N2

text: Was the American Revolution such a good idea? https://t.co/lVmiEz25s8

text: "Social distancing cannot cure or defeat COVID-19. It only allows us to hide from the virus while scientists do their work," writes Howard Markel, who helped develop the concept now known as "flattening the curve." https://t.co/h9HQ9sWaFM

text: If Chinese national-security officials had hoped to make an example out of Jimmy Lai to cow dissenters, it failed, @JiayangFan writes. https://t.co/I1LrkgYeHi

text: What comes after flattening the curve? The challenge is keeping it flat—“holding the line”—not just for months but perhaps for years, writes Howard Markel, who helped develop the concept. https://t.co/xucke2MxZv

text: The need to address China’s economic practices is clear. But President Trump’s fixation on TikTok serves only as a distraction, and highlights just how inadequate his Administration’s response has been. https://t.co/U2v46FAgXd

text: "For those who can take a stolen moment of repose, the Nap Dress has a tranquillizing allure," @rachsyme writes. "It is a clean slate, white noise, a gauzy, brief escape for those who can afford it." https://t.co/fVNv7UWJoe

name: NewYorker
text: For the past 40 years, Republicans have been seeking to starve, strangle, and sabotage the U.S.P.S., hoping to privatize one of the oldest and most important public goods in American history. https://t.co/lf3bu4K4WW

name: NewYorker
text: A letter from Jeff Bezos, in @tnyshouts: "Though it’s true that the pandemic has brought the world to its knees, it also has the power to bring us together, and in little, unseen ways it can even make us billions more dollars than we were making before." https://t.co/fV6GePYIg3
